title: TCS Research and Innovation Interview Experience for Researcher Role
content:
TCS Research and Innovation recruits researchers from tier-1 institutes, targeting both B.Tech and M.Tech students. The shortlisting process is primarily based on candidates’ research potential and domain expertise. During the application, we were asked to choose our preferred domain for the interview. I selected Deep Learning and AI as my primary area of interest. A total of 9 students from both B.Tech and M.Tech programs were shortlisted for the role, and I was fortunate to be one of them. 
Recruitment Process Overview
Resume Shortlisting
Technical + Managerial Interview 
HR
Round 1: Resume Shortlisting
After my resume was shortlisted, I proceeded to the following interview rounds:
Round 2: Technical + Managerial Interview 
The technical interview panel consisted of four senior-level scientists from TCS Research. The round commenced with a brief self-introduction, followed by a detailed discussion of my primary research project. I was asked to walk them through the complete pipeline, starting from dataset collection to selecting the most appropriate computational metrics for evaluating my model.
1. Technical Questions
Here are some key technical questions I was asked:
What problem are you solving, and why do you believe it is important to address?
Could you explain your dataset in detail? How did you handle high dimensionality in your dataset?
What feature engineering techniques did you apply?
How did you handle missing values?
Why did you choose KNN imputation?
How can outliers be detected and treated effectively?
Explain the concepts of box plots, standardization, and normalization. Why are these techniques necessary?
Which model did you choose and why?
Explain how OPTUNA works in brief.
What optimization algorithm did you use, and how does it function?
When should one use R² score over accuracy, and vice versa?
Following this, I was asked to elaborate on a particular feature of one of my personal NLP projects. I had to explain the complete pipeline in detail—highlighting each step, the choice of libraries, reasons for their selection over alternatives, and their impact on the overall time complexity.
2. Managerial Round
The 
managerial round
 immediately followed the technical interview. During this round, I was asked questions to assess my interpersonal and decision-making skills, as well as my ability to thrive in a professional setting.
Some of the questions I was asked included:
How do you justify your suitability for this role, competing against top-tier CSE/IT students?
Which research lab do you currently work in and under which professor?
Why aren't you working under a professor from the CSE department?
In the context of ML for medical applications, who do you think is better suited: someone from a non-core background like yours or someone with a biology background?
Since machine learning was not a part of your formal coursework, how did you learn it and how credible are your sources of learning?
Are you open to relocation, if required?
Do you have any questions for us?
These questions gave me an opportunity to express my passion for research and how my diverse background contributed to my growth in the field of Machine Learning and AI.
Round 3: 
HR Round
The HR round was quite relaxed. I was asked general questions related to my background, academic journey, and CGPA.
Verdict : Selected

title: ZopSmart Interview Experience for SDE Intern
content:
Recently, I had the opportunity to interview for a Software Development Engineer (SDE) internship with ZopSmart, a retail tech company known for providing digital transformation solutions. The hiring process was intensive and structured across multiple rounds, thoroughly evaluating both technical skills and soft skills. Here's a detailed breakdown of my experience:
How I Received the Interview Call?
I received the interview opportunity through on-campus recruitment at Chandigarh University. ZopSmart opened the SDE internship role to eligible students, attracting over 1700 applicants. The selection process was extremely competitive, with only 5 candidates making it through all the rounds.
Recruitment Process Overview
Online Assessment 1
Online Assessment 2 
Group Discussion (GD)
Technical Interview 1
Technical Interview 2
HR Interview
Round 1: Online Assessment (OA - Screening)
Duration
: 1 hour
Method:
 Online (automated test)
This was the initial screening round. It comprised two easy-level problems focused on 
string manipulation
 and 
logic building
. The questions were direct but required clarity in basic string operations and programming logic.
Outcome:
 Top 200 candidates selected from 1700+ applicants
Round 2: Online Assessment (OA - Elimination)
Duration:
 1 hour
Method
: Online
The second round was more challenging, emphasizing 
mathematical logic
 and 
problem-solving
. It featured two medium-level problems involving 
math-based algorithms
, requiring strong analytical thinking and accuracy.
Outcome:
 Shortlisted 40 candidates for further rounds
Round 3: Group Discussion (GD)
Topic
: Should freshers say yes to every task given to them?
Duration
: 30 minutes
This round aimed to assess 
communication skills
, 
clarity of thought
, and 
confidence
 in a group setting. The key challenge was balancing assertiveness with humility in a room full of competitive candidates.
Outcome
: 20–25 candidates moved forward
Round 4: Technical Interview 1
Duration
: 25-30 minutes
Mode
: In-person/Video
The first technical interview evaluated candidates on 
Core Java
, 
SQL
, and 
Data Structures
.
Discussion Topics:
Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) concepts in Java
SQL queries involving joins
Coding Problem: 
Print the right view of a binary tree
Challenge:
 Properly handling edge cases in tree traversal logic
Outcome
: 10–15 candidates moved forward
Round 5: Technical Interview 2
Duration
: 30-40 minutes
This round went deeper into 
project experience
, 
advanced SQL
, and 
DSA
.
Discussion Topics:
Detailed walk-through of a personal project, covering design, challenges, and outcomes
Advanced SQL: joins, sub-queries, filtering
Coding Problem: 
Reverse Linked List in Variable-Sized Groups
(first group - 1st node, second group - next 2 nodes, and so on…)
Challenge:
 Handling group-wise iteration and pointer manipulation effectively
Outcome:
 7–8 candidates were shortlisted for the final HR round.
Round 6: HR Round
Duration: 
10 minutes
This final round assessed 
personality
 and 
soft skills
.
Discussion Topics:
Self-introduction
Hobbies, strengths, and weaknesses
Motivation for joining ZopSmart
Outcome:
 5 candidates, including myself, were selected for the SDE Internship offer.

title: TCS Ninja Interview Experience
content:
As a final-year student based in Pune, Maharashtra, I had the exciting opportunity to participate in the TCS Ninja interview process in May 2025. This interview was crucial for my career, and I prepared diligently for each stage. Here’s a breakdown of my experience during the interview process and the lessons I learned along the way.
Recruitment Overview Process
The TCS recruitment  process was divided into four main rounds:
Initial Screening
Technical Round
Managerial Round
HR Round
Each round had a specific focus, testing different skills and attributes required for the role. Let me take you through each of these rounds in detail.
Round 1: Initial Screening
Duration
: 190 mins
Method
: Online Aptitude and Coding Assessment
Focus
: General aptitude, reasoning, and basic coding
The first stage of the interview was the online assessment, which included two main parts: 
aptitude
 and 
coding
. The assessment aimed to evaluate my problem-solving ability, speed, and coding proficiency. Here's what I encountered:
1.1 Aptitude Section:
The aptitude questions covered fundamental topics such as:
Time, speed & distance
Profit & loss
Number series
These topics required a strong understanding of mathematics and logic. I spent a considerable amount of time practicing these questions to improve my problem-solving speed and accuracy.
1.2 Coding Section:
In the coding part, the questions focused on:
Pattern printing
Basic recursion-based logic
I had to implement solutions for pattern printing and solve simple recursive problems. These questions were designed to test my ability to think algorithmically and write clean code under time pressure.
Round 2: Technical Round
Duration:
 45 minutes
Method:
 Offline Interview
Focus
: Projects, core CS concepts, and technology stack used
After successfully clearing the initial screening, I moved on to the 
Technical Round
. This was an offline interview that delved into my projects and core computer science concepts. The interview was interactive and covered the following topics:
Basic Questions:
Introduce yourself
Explain your major and minor projects
Follow-up questions on project flow, tech stack, and challenges faced
Technologies used in projects: Frameworks, databases, version control
Technical Concepts:
OOPs Concepts: Polymorphism, Inheritance, Encapsulation
Explain Abstraction with a real-life example
Differences between public, private, and protected access specifiers
Role of the friend keyword in C++
Basics of views, indexes, and stored procedures in SQL
This round tested not only my technical knowledge but also how well I could communicate complex topics and solutions.
Round 3: Managerial Round
Duration
: 30 minutes
Method
: Offline Interview
Focus
: Problem-solving ability, personality traits, resume-based discussion
The 
Managerial Round
 was designed to assess my problem-solving ability, personality, and how I would fit into the company culture. Here, I faced a mix of technical and personal questions:
Key Questions:
Write a code to calculate factorial of a number
Discuss your hobbies and how you pursue them
What certifications have you done? (Asked about relevance to job role)
Deep dive into some bullet points from the resume
Round 4: HR 
Duration
: 15 minutes
Method
: Offline Interview
Focus
: Cultural fit, job flexibility, and expectations
Finally, I entered the 
HR Round
, which was more about cultural fit and understanding my expectations for the role. The HR interviewer asked a few basic but important questions:
Key Questions:
Where is your hometown?
Are you okay with relocation?
Are you comfortable working night shifts?
Are you genuinely interested in joining TCS?
Final Outcome
I gave the TCS Ninja interview after thoroughly preparing the basics of computer science fundamentals, SQL, and the technologies mentioned in my resume. This focused preparation really helped me tackle both the technical and managerial rounds with confidence. The interviewers were supportive throughout the process. In the HR round, after a brief discussion, I was delighted to hear the words, 
"You are selected for the interview."
 It was a memorable and rewarding experience.

title: Goldman Sachs Interview Experience for Strats Associate
content:
I recently interviewed for the 
Strats role
 in the 
AWM Strats
 department at 
Goldman Sachs
. The interview process was rigorous and consisted of multiple rounds, each focusing on different aspects of my technical and behavioural skills. Although I was ultimately rejected, the experience provided invaluable insights and helped me grow both professionally and personally.
Recruitment Process Overview
Initial Screening: Exploratory Round
Coding Round
Technical Round I
Technical Round II
Round 1: Initial Screening: Exploratory Round
The first round was an exploratory call that lasted around 
30 minutes
 via 
video call
. This round was more about understanding my future aspirations and whether I would be a good fit for the role.
Key Questions
Introduce yourself and explain your background.
What are your future goals, and why are you targeting the Strats role?
Why Goldman Sachs and what interests you about this department?
Obstacles:
 No obstacle as such, cleared the round smoothly.
Round 2: Coding Round
The 
Coding round
 lasted 
1 hour
 and was conducted via 
video call
. This round was focused on problem-solving and testing my Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA) knowledge.
Key Questions
Chessboard Problem:
The question asked about a bishop on an 8x8 chessboard. I was given the starting and target coordinates and had to find the minimum number of moves for the bishop to reach the target. If it was impossible, I needed to return -1.
After some brainstorming, I identified the pattern and solved it successfully, passing all test cases within 
30 minutes
.
Trapping Rainwater Problem:
I skipped the brute force approach and quickly suggested using the 
prefix and suffix array approach
 to solve this problem. However, due to time constraints, I was unable to implement the solution completely.
Obstacles
: I touched DSA last in December 2022, so I was a bit slow and underprepared for the interview, I was even facing difficulty in the syntax but the interviewer understood and helped me a bit with cpp syntax.
Round 3: Technical Round I
The 
Technical Round I
 lasted for 
1 hour
 and was conducted via 
video call
. This round was a 
panel interview
 with two interviewers. The questions started off easy but progressively became more challenging.
 
Key Questions
Puzzle Question:
The interview started with a 
puzzle
 (
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/puzzle-18-torch-and-bridge/
), which I struggled to solve. I was moving in the right direction but couldn’t finish in time.
Reverse a Number:
The interviewers asked me to reverse a number, a basic question. I explained my approach and coded the solution. We discussed edge cases like integer overflow, and I explained how I would handle those cases.
Arithmetic Progression in an Array:
I was asked how to check if an array's elements form an 
Arithmetic Progression
. I initially suggested sorting the array and checking the difference between consecutive elements. The interviewer asked me to optimize it, and I came up with a 
Hashmap approach
 which they were satisfied with.
Obstacles
: I faced minor lags because I had lost touch with coding from sometime. Also, not able to solve puzzle caused a bit of panic to me.
Round 4: Technical Round II
This round took place just 
15 minutes
 after the previous one, making it a bit challenging to recover fully. The round lasted 
1 hour
 and was again conducted via 
video call
.
Key Questions
Remove Consecutive Characters from String:
I was asked to solve the problem where consecutive characters in a string need to be removed. I first provided the 
brute force solution
 and then optimized it using a 
stack
 approach. The solution passed all test cases.
Square Root of a Decimal to 4 Decimal Places:
The second question was about finding the 
square root of a decimal
 to 
4 decimal places
. I proposed the 
binary search approach
, but I struggled to handle the precision for four decimal places in the code. The interviewer acknowledged my thought process but noted that I needed to improve on implementing it within the time frame.
Obstacles
: The second question was a bit googly for me and I was stuck due to that 4 decimal place criteria.
Verdict: Rejected

title: Dentsu  Interview Experience for Associate Business Analyst (Intern)
content:
After applying, I received an email from Dentsu’s HR team within 3 days, notifying me that my resume had been shortlisted. The email contained further details about the internship and the interview process. The selection process consisted of four rounds and was completed within 1 week. All the interviews were conducted virtually.
Recruitment Overview Process
Aptitude Assessment
Jombay Behavioural Assessment
Articulation Round
HR Round
Round 1: Aptitude Assessment
The first assessment link was shared via email the next day.
Duration:
 40 minutes
Questions
: 25 aptitude-based questions
Difficulty
: Easy to moderate
Participants
: 800+ candidates
Outcome:
 I cleared this round comfortably.
Round 2:
 Jombay Behavioural Assessment
The next day, I received a link for the second assessment.
Type:
 Behavioural test (situation-based questions)
Questions
: Around 100
Focus: 
Personality, decision-making, ethics
Shortlisted Candidates:
 Reduced to about 200 after this round
Outcome
: I cleared this round as well.
Round 3: Articulation Round
This was the most interesting round. I attended it two days later.
The HR was 
extremely polite, friendly
, and made everyone feel at ease.
She introduced herself and explained the company’s vision and values.
Questions asked included:
Who is your favourite pet and why?
Do miracles happen around us?
Your thoughts on social media and long-distance relationships.
Essay-style prompts similar to school English papers.
Preferences for location and specialization.
Tips:
Also be ready for guesstimate and puzzle-based questions, such as:
How many people in your city use iPhones?
How many people in India wear a red cap?
Important Note:
Students from Computer Science Engineering backgrounds were disqualified at this stage. The HR clearly stated they were not eligible. (Luckily, I'm from Artificial Intelligence and Data Science, so I was eligible.)
Total candidates left: About 50
Attended this round: Only 34
Round 4: HR
This round was conversational and relaxed.
Questions included:
Tell me about yourself
How does this role fit your background?
Where do you see yourself in 3–5 years?
What are your strengths and weaknesses?
A few simple scenario-based questions
Note
: This opportunity is strictly for freshers, not for experienced professionals.
Final Outcome
Overall, I’m very satisfied with the way Dentsu handled the hiring process. It was professional yet friendly, well-organized yet informal in tone, which really helped reduce the pressure. I'm grateful for the opportunity and hopeful for the outcome. I was selected.
Post-Interview Reflections:
The entire screening process was very smooth, well-structured, and stress-free.
I really appreciated how kind and supportive the HRs were at every stage.
As this was my first-ever interview, I was nervous initially, but the positive environment helped me stay confident.
My Advice:
Be honest in your responses and resume.
Don’t over-prepare or fake confidence—just be yourself.
Prepare for basic behavioral, logical, and articulation-based questions.

title: Cognizant Interview Experience - GENC Next Role - 2025
content:
This is about my recent interview experience with Cognizant, which is a pool campus drive in February; 2025. The recruitment process was well-structured and consisted of four rounds: a Versant Test, an Aptitude + Reasoning (Game-Based) Round, a Technical Assessment, and finally a combined Technical + HR Interview.
Recruitment Process Overview
The Cognizant recruitment process had 4 rounds:
Versant Test
Aptitude + Reasoning (Game-Based Assessment)
Technical Assessment
Technical + HR Interview 
Round 1: Versant Test
Versant Test
 is conducted through AMCAT 
Duration:
 60 minutes
The Versant Test is designed to evaluate a candidate's spoken  English Communication skills, which are crucial for roles involving client interaction and global collaboration. This was an automated voice-based assessment, where candidates interact with a computer-generated voice.
Round 2: Aptitude + Reasoning (Game-Based Assessment)
Mode:
 Online
Duration
: 80 minutes
Platform:
 AMCAT 
This round was a game-based cognitive ability assessment designed to measure a candidate's mental agility, decision-making speed, and logical reasoning through a serios of interactive games. 
Tips:
No need for prior practice; it's about being focused, quick, and accurate.
Read instructions carefully before each game starts.
Stay calm, as the games can be fast-paced but intuitive.
Good hand-eye coordination and presence of mind will help.
Round 3: Technical Assessment
Mode
: Online
Duration:
 120 minutes
Platform
: AMCAT
 
Section 1: SQL (2 Questions)
This section tested your ability to write and understand SQL queries.
Questions included:
Writing queries using JOIN, GROUP BY, WHERE, and aggregate functions.
Understanding query output or optimizing SQL logic.
Tip
: Be thorough with INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, subqueries, and basic database concepts like normalization and keys.
Section 2: Programming (2 Questions)
Candidates could choose their preferred language from 
C#, Java
, or 
Python.
The questions tested logical thinking, problem-solving, and code efficiency.
Common topics:
String manipulation, 
arrays/lists, loops, conditionals
Functions and basic 
object-oriented programming
Sample problems - Palindrome check, sorting, pattern printing, frequency count
Tip:
 Practice medium-level coding questions and be comfortable using functions, loops, and built-in methods in your chosen language.
Section 3: Web Development (1 Question)
This section had one question focused on basic front-end web technologies.
Topics included:
Writing
 HTML/CSS
 code to create or style a given layout
Understanding of tags, form elements, CSS properties
Sometimes basic JavaScript logic (optional)
Tip: 
Brush up on HTML5 tags, CSS basics (positioning, flexbox, colors), and simple form handling.
 
Preparation Tips
Practice SQL queries on platforms like GFG - 
SQL Concept and Queries
.
Strengthen programming logic in your chosen language.
Review basic front-end development (HTML/CSS) using interactive platforms like 
Web Development
 - GFG
Round 4: Technical + HR Interview
Mode: 
Hybrid
Duration:
 90 minutes
This final round was a combination of technical and HR evaluation, conducted by two technical interviewers—one interacted with me in person, while the other joined virtually via the Superset platform. Both panelists were friendly and supportive, which helped ease the tension and allowed for smooth interaction.
Technical Evaluation:
The interviewers thoroughly assessed my understanding of core computer science concepts, programming, and real-world application knowledge.
Topics Covered:
Object-Oriented Programming (OOPs):
Concepts like inheritance, polymorphism, encapsulation, abstraction
Real-life examples and how OOPs applies in projects
DBMS & SQL
:
SQL queries (JOINS, GROUP BY, aggregate functions)
Normalization forms and use cases
Relational schema and ER to table conversion
Basic DSA (Data Structures & Algorithms):
Arrays, strings, and basic sorting/searching logic
Time complexity-related discussions
Coding Section:
I was asked to write 4 coding problems during the interview. These were mostly:
Based on strings and arrays
Involved logic building using OOPs concepts
Some problems required SQL query writing as well
The coding was done live, and I was expected to explain the logic, optimize if possible, and handle edge cases.
Final Outcome
After successfully clearing all four rounds, I was finally selected for the Programmer Analyst role at Cognizant. The results were announced nearly a month after the interview process concluded, and interestingly, they were declared after the results for the GenC profile were released.
Overall, the process was well-structured, smooth, and candidate-friendly. The interviewers were approachable and supportive, especially during the final round, which made the experience less stressful and more conversational.

title: iBirds Software Services Interview Experience for Fresher 2025 {Off-Campus Interview Experience}
content:
Hey everyone! I recently appeared for the iBirds Software Services off-campus drive on May 30th, and I wanted to share my experience here. The drive had around 127 candidates, and by the end, only 15 students were selected. I was fortunate to be one of them and secured a Java Developer Intern role. Though the process was challenging, I learned a lot and hope this post helps someone preparing for it in the future.
Recruitment Process Overview:
Aptitude Round
Coding Round
Technical Interview
Director Round
Round 1: Aptitude Round
This was the first filtration round.
1. Total Questions: 60
30 Java MCQs:
 Focused on core Java and advanced Java concepts
30 Basic Mathematics:
 Quantitative aptitude, qualitative aptitude, abstract reasoning, and logical reasoning
2. Duration:
 60 minutes
3. Level: 
Moderate
4. Shortlisted Candidates: 
92 from 127
Outcome:
 I was one of the 92 candidates who cleared this round. The questions were manageable if you have a good grasp of Java fundamentals and basic math skills.
Round 2: Coding Round
This was a coding round with 3 sets of questions, each containing 4 questions. I got Set 2.
My Set (Set 2) Questions:
Longest Palindromic Substring - DP Question
Best Time to Buy and Sell Stocks II - Array Question
Reverse Nodes in K-Group - Recursion + LinkedList (only the function was implemented to test logic building)
My friends got set 1 and set 3 , which i menmtioned below
Set 1 Questions:
Minimum Window Substring - String Question
Two Sum - Array Question
Search in BST - Tree Question

Shortlisted Candidates:

Outcome: 
I was among the 45 shortlisted for the next round. The questions in Set 2 were of medium difficulty, and practicing DP, arrays, and linked lists beforehand really helped.
Round 3: Technical Interview
This round was a face-to-face technical interview.
Topics Covered:
Core Java and Advanced Java concepts
Basic SQL Queries
OOPS Concepts
DSA Question: Count the size of elements in an array
First, I gave a brute force solution
Then, I was asked to optimize it, and I provided an optimized approach using a HashMap
Shortlisted Candidates:
 20 from 45
Outcome:
 I cleared this round as well. The interviewer was friendly and focused on testing my problem-solving approach and clarity in explaining concepts.
Round 4: Director Round
This was the final face-to-face round with the director. It was more about assessing communication, confidence, and fit for the role.
Shortlisted Candidates:
 15 from 20
Outcome:
 I was one of the 15 candidates who cleared this round and got selected for the Java Developer Intern role at iBirds Software Services!
Additional Tips
Prepare well for Java:
 Both core and advanced Java are crucial.
Practice DSA thoroughly:
 Focus on arrays, linked lists, and dynamic programming.
Get comfortable with SQL:
 Basic queries are often asked in technical interviews.
Stay calm and confident:
 Even if you struggle, your approach and attitude matter.
Final Outcome
I’m thrilled to share that I secured the Java Developer Intern role at iBirds Software Services! The process was challenging but rewarding, and I’m excited to start this new journey. To anyone preparing for iBirds, focus on your fundamentals and problem-solving skills — it’ll definitely pay off.
Best of luck — keep learning and growing!

title: My TCS Prime Interview Experience – 9 LPA Offer
content:
Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) has selected candidates for the TCS Prime profile, offering an impressive package of 9 LPA, although those selected for the Ninja profile will receive a package of 3.33 LPA. This recruitment is taking place at Lovely Professional University for the 2025 batch. The TCS NQT exam is scheduled for October 2024, and the interview process will take place on 4th December 2024. This on-campus recruitment provides students with a valuable opportunity to join one of the world’s leading IT services companies.
How I Got the Interview Call
I registered for the TCS NQT (National Qualifier Test) through my college’s campus placement cell. After taking the test in October 2024, I was shortlisted for the TCS Prime interview round based on my performance, especially in the coding section, where I solved both questions.
Rounds of Selection
TCS NQT (Written Test)
Single Technical + Managerial + HR Interview (All combined in one) This test was conducted at a TCS iON center.
Round 1: TCS NQT (Written Test)
The test was divided into the following sections:
1.1 Aptitude & Reasoning
Verbal Ability
1.2 Coding Questions
Find the average of elements in an array.
Another medium-level array problem.
Obstacles:
 I was able to solve both questions within the time limit.
Round 2: Interview (1 Hour | Panel of 3)
1. Introduction
The panel started by asking me to introduce myself.
I shared details about my background, technical skills, and projects.
2. Technical Round
They asked me to solve the same coding question from the NQT test:
Find the average of elements in an array.
Follow-up questions:
What is an average?
Write the code and explain it line-by-line.
3. Project Discussion
I explained my major project in detail.
Tech used - Cloud services, backend APIs, database integration.
Follow-up Questions:
What is Cloud Computing?
Why do we need cloud platforms?
Real-world use cases of cloud technology.
4. AI/ML Basics
What is Artificial Intelligence?
What is Machine Learning?
Examples of ML applications (e.g., recommendation systems, fraud detection).
5. HR Questions
Why is your CGPA low?
How do you stay self-motivated despite setbacks?
What’s the difference between TCS Ninja, Digital, and Prime?
If selected for TCS Ninja, would you still join?
Final Result
Though I was interviewed for the Prime role (9 LPA), I was finally offered the TCS Ninja role (3.33 LPA). Still, it was a great experience and boosted my confidence.
Tips for Aspirants
Revise the coding questions you solved in NQT — you may be asked to explain them again.
Know your projects thoroughly — be ready to explain every tech stack used.
Prepare basics of Cloud Computing, AI, and ML.
Be ready to answer HR questions sincerely — especially about CGPA and role preference.
Stay confident, calm, and structured in your responses.
Keep preparing and don’t lose heart — every interview is a stepping stone to something better. All the best!

title: Hyland Software Interview Experience: Developer 2  (2025)
content:
I recently interviewed for the Developer 2 role at Hyland Software. The process involved three rounds of evaluation, primarily focused on 
Angular, TypeScript, Data Structures, and Software Design principles
. Although I was selected, the position was eventually closed as the project for which hiring was initiated did not kick off as planned.
Recruitment Overview Process
Technical Screening
Technical Round
Managerial Round
Round 1: Technical Screening (DSA + JavaScript)
This round was conducted virtually and involved data structures and algorithms, along with JavaScript-based problem solving .I was asked to implement logic for problems involving arrays, string manipulation, and time complexity optimization. He round also touched on JavaScript concepts such as closures, promises, and event loop.
Round 2: Frontend Technical Round
This was a deep-dive into Angular and TypeScript.
Topics included:
Component communication
Angular lifecycle hooks
Reactive programming using RxJS
Writing unit tests using Jest and Karma
Real-world debugging scenarios
I was also asked to walk through a mini system design of a front-end module using SOLID principles and best practices.
Round 3: Managerial + System Design Round
This was a combination of managerial and high-level technical discussion.
Discussion around, Previous project architecture
Collaboration within cross-functional teams
Designing a scalable component library
Understanding of CI/CD, test automation, and code review processes
Behavioral questions to assess cultural fit and problem-solving under constraints
Final Outcome
I received positive feedback from all three rounds and was informed that I had been selected. However, the hiring process was eventually halted as the project the company had planned to onboard for was put on hold.

title: TCS Interview Experience | TCS NQT 2025 | Prime Category | Off-campus
content:
I applied for the 
TCS NQT
 through the NextStep portal, which my college guided me through in February 2025. I received the admit card 15 days before the exam, which had all the necessary details about the exam centre, instructions, and schedule. The exam was conducted in March 2025 at a designated centre for the role of TCS Prime Category.
TCS NQT Pattern and Experience
The test was divided into sections:
Numerical Ability
Verbal Ability
Reasoning Ability
Advanced Quantitative Ability
Advanced Reasoning Ability
Hands-on Coding (2 problems)
Each section had its own timer, and once the time ended, it automatically moved to the next, so 
time management is very important.
I found the overall test manageable, but I spent too much time on Numerical Ability, so I couldn't complete it entirely. The coding section was quite easy, but the trick was in understanding the question requirements clearly.
The coding problems were:
Find the LCM 
of two numbers
Find the Frequency of elements 
in an array (moderate level, involved an election-type logic)
The questions were lengthy in wording, so I had to carefully read the sample test cases to figure out the exact requirement. Each problem had 
7 test cases - 
2 public and 5 hidden. I was able to pass 7/7 in the first and 5/7 in the second
I used 
Python, 
and thankfully, everything worked well - but be cautious about indentation issues, as some of my peers faced errors due to that. 
Interview Call (Prime Category)
I received my interview call for the Prime category in May 2025, around 1.5 months after the NQT exam. The mail asked me to fill a form to choose my preferred interview location. After that, I received another mail with the final interview date and venue. The interview was conducted in person at TCS Chennai, starting with document verification, followed by panel allotment.
Each panel had three interviewers:
Technical Interview
Managerial Interview
HR/Personal Interview
1. Technical Round:
This was a one-on-one session where the interviewer focused mainly on my resume, internship and practical experience.
Questions Asked:
Tell me about your internship experience.
What was your role and contribution in the internship?
Which tech stack did you use during your internship?
How did your internship experience help you improve as a developer?
What is GitHub? What are Git commits, and how do you manage version control?
What is JavaScript Destructuring, and where have you used it?
Given a pattern, explain how you'll print it and write the code.
Coding task: Find frequency of elements in an array.
Which project from your resume has the most real-world impact? Why?
Justify the problem it solves and how it helps.
2. Managerial Round:
This round assessed my 
leadership, decision-making, and technical awareness.
Questions Asked:
If your entire team is more experienced than you, how would you manage?
How would you deal with team members who don't support you
Are you comfortable working with unknown or diverse teams? (with follow-up questions)
Have you taken the lead in any project or team activity before?
Do you know about cloud computing?
What are its types?
What is PAAS? 
What kind of service is Google Drive?
Give example for PaaS and SaaS.
What is Private Cloud and Hybrid Cloud?
3. HR/Personal Round:
This was a casual and reflective round.
Questions Asked:
Have you attended any interviews before this one?
Have you received offers from any companies?
Are you still working with the same company or has it concluded?
What challenges did you face during your internship?
Are you open to relocation and flexible with work timings?
Closing Thoughts & Tips
My overall TCS interview experience was smooth, professional, and highly structured. The panelists were friendly, but focused on evaluating practical knowledge, adaptability, and clear communication.
Here are a few key takeaways and tips from my journey:
 Be confident when explaining your projects and internship—know your contribution, tech stack, and learning outcomes.
 Keep your resume simple and honest. Questions will be based directly on it.
 Be ready for questions on current technologies like cloud computing, blockchain, 5G, or even AI/ML—even basic awareness can help.
 If you’ve worked on a final year project or research paper, prepare to discuss it in depth.
 Practice coding basics, pattern printing, and logical questions—they care more about your thought process than just correct syntax.
Communication is key. Think aloud and explain your approach clearly, even if you’re unsure of the exact answer.
As of now (June 2025), I am still awaiting the final result. Hoping for a positive outcome!  All the best to anyone preparing for TCS NQT or interviews! You've got this.

title: SHELL Interview Experience for Associate Software Engineer
content:
I recently appeared for an on-campus interview conducted by Shell for the role of Associate Software Engineer. Shell is a global group of energy and petrochemical companies, known for its expertise in petroleum, natural gas, and lubricants. The company offers dynamic career opportunities and values innovation and sustainability in its operations.
Candidate Information
Status
: Placed
Experience
: 1+ years of relevant experience (including internship/project work)
Target Position
: Associate Software Engineer
Location
: Delhi
Interview Date
: 4th Oct, 2024
Recruitment  Process Overview
Resume Shortlisting
Online Test
Technical + HR Interview
Round 1: Resume Shortlisting
Resume Shortlisting
Focus: Initial evaluation based on qualifications, projects, and relevant experience
Outcome: Selected for further rounds
Round 2: Online Test
Duration
: 2 hours
Method
: Online
Focus
: Data Structures & Algorithms, SQL, Aptitude
Structure
: 4 Sections, 48 Questions in total
 Question on DSA Section
:
Problem 1
: A combinatorics problem involving counting how many different paint combinations can be created using at most Y paints from X options, including original paints.
Problem 2
: A graph theory problem requiring the shortest path between two nodes (John and Dave) in an undirected graph, representing the fewest number of relatives in a gift transfer chain.
 Question on  SQL Section
: 
Basic to intermediate-level query problems involving table operations and data filtering.
 Question on Aptitude Section
:
General logical reasoning and mathematical aptitude questions.
Obstacles
: Not any.
Round 3: Technical + HR Interview
I received the interview call through an official email from Shell and was also informed about the opportunity by my college faculty. Here is a detailed breakdown of my interview process:
Duration
: 1 hour
Method
: Video Call
Focus
: Resume-based HR questions and conceptual technical understanding
HR Questions
:
Personal introduction
Details about past projects and internships
Teamwork and collaboration experiences
Technical Questions
:
Explanation of Tortoise and Hare Algorithm for detecting cycles in a linked list
Multiple follow-up questions on Linked Lists and how to solve common problems
Conceptual discussion on Exception Handling in Java, specifically the roles of try, catch, and finally blocks
Obstacles
: No major obstacles, but the mixed format required switching between HR and technical topics quickly.
Note
: No live coding was required; the interviewer focused on understanding and explanation of concepts and algorithms.
Post-Interview Reflections
Company Culture Insights
: The interviewer was friendly and attentive, which reflected a collaborative and learning-focused culture.
Work Environment
: As the interview was virtual, there was limited exposure to the workplace environment, but communication was clear and professional.
Benefits Highlight
: Benefits were not discussed during the interview.
Evaluator Feedback
: While direct feedback was not provided, the interviewer seemed satisfied with the clarity and depth of answers during the technical discussion.
Suggestions for Improvement
: A clearer separation between HR and technical sections during the interview could help candidates prepare and perform more confidently.
Additional Information
Selected candidates were informed within two days of the online test. The interview was scheduled three days after the result announcement.
Closing Note
Overall, the interview experience was smooth and well-organized. The questions tested both conceptual understanding and the ability to explain technical logic clearly. I appreciated the opportunity to share my experience and learnings and am looking forward to the next steps.

title: My Interview Experience at A.P. Moller - Maersk
content:
The interview process at A.P. Moller - Maersk was structured, professional and campus-driven with a strong focus on both technical depth and cultural alignment. Maersk visited our campus -The National Institute of Engineering, Mysore in June 2025 as part of their campus hiring initiative. The company was hiring for the Software Development Engineer (SDE) role. They were specifically looking for candidates with strong proficiency in C# and the .NET framework, as these technologies are central to their development stack.
Application Status:
Total Applicants:
 Around 250 students
Eligible Branches
: Computer Science (CS), Information Science (IS)
Shortlisted for Online Assessment
: Approximately 200 students
Cleared Online Assessment (Moved to Technical Round)
: 82 students
Cleared Technical Round (Moved to Managerial Round)
: 35 students
Shortlisted for Final HR Discussion
: 20 students
Final Offers Made
: 13 students
Round 1: Online Assessment
The first round was an Online Assessment conducted on the CoCubes platform by AON. It served as an elimination round and was designed to test candidates across multiple skill areas relevant to the role. The assessment consisted of the following sections:
C# and .NET Fundamentals:
 This section included multiple choice questions focused on core concepts of the C# programming language, the .NET framework and LINQ queries. A strong understanding of object-oriented principles and common .NET components was essential.
SQL Queries:
 Questions in this section tested the candidate’s ability to write and interpret SQL queries, including basic joins, aggregations and filtering operations.
Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA):
 This section included one coding question. The problem I encountered was: "Flip bits at even positions" The task was to manipulate a given binary number such that bits at even positions were flipped, requiring knowledge of bitwise operations and indexing logic.
English Language Assessment:
 In this section, candidates were given a topic and asked to write a short passage of approximately 150–180 words. This tests communication skills, grammar and the ability to express thoughts coherently.
Round 2: Technical Interview
The Technical Round was conducted virtually and lasted about 30–45 minutes. It began with the interviewer asking me to introduce myself and briefly talk about my technical background including the programming languages and frameworks I’m most proficient in. The discussion then moved on to the projects listed on my resume with a strong focus on my architectural decisions and implementation choices. The interviewer asked a mix of project specific, conceptual and practical SQL/database questions along with a few behavioral queries toward the end. 
Few Questions from My Interview :
1. Why have you used GraphQL as the API Gateway ?
Answer:
 GraphQL provides flexible querying, avoids overfetching and under fetching and serves multiple frontend needs efficiently through a single endpoint.
2. Why microservices and not monolith?
Answer:
 Microservices offer better scalability, modular development  and fault isolation compared to monoliths.
3. What are the advantages of RabbitMQ over Kafka?
Answer:
 RabbitMQ is easier to set up , better for low-latency message delivery and has strong support for message acknowledgements and retries.
4. What if the size of RabbitMQ grows very big? How do you manage it?
Answer:
 Use TTL (Time-To-Live) policies, dead-letter queues and periodic cleanup strategies to manage message size and queues.
5. Difference between Access Token and Refresh Token?
Answer:
 Access Token is short lived and used to access resources. Refresh Token is long lived and used to get new access tokens.
6. Why do we need two tokens? Can’t we just extend the access token’s life?
Answer:
 Two tokens improve security. Short lived access tokens reduce risk if compromised and refresh tokens allow secure re-authentication.
7. What is normalization?
Answer:
 Normalization is the process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity.
8. Why is normalization important?
Answer:
 It ensures data consistency, eliminates duplicate data and maintains database efficiency.
9. Which relational and non-relational databases have you worked with and why?
Answer: 
Relational: MySQL, PostgreSQL  for structured and relational data.Non-relational: MongoDB  for flexible schema and better scalability.
10. What is the basic difference between relational and non-relational databases?
Answer:
 Relational uses structured tables with schemas. Non-relational stores data as documents or key value pairs offering schema flexibility.
11. Write SQL queries on JOINs, GROUP BY, HAVING clause, and aggregate functions.
Answer (Example):
 SELECT d.name, COUNT(e.id) FROM employee e JOIN department d ON e.dept_id = d.id GROUP BY d.name HAVING COUNT(e.id) > 5;
12. What are the types of JOINs?
Answer:
 INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, FULL OUTER JOIN.
13. Is LEFT JOIN and LEFT OUTER JOIN the same?
Answer:
 Yes they are the same. LEFT JOIN is a shorthand for LEFT OUTER JOIN.
14. What is the advantage of using Kafka in your chat app project?
Answer
: Kafka supports high throughput, horizontal scalability and ensures reliable real-time message streaming across services.
15. How do you ensure scalability in your system?
Answer
: Use stateless services, load balancers, database sharding, horizontal scaling and caching mechanisms.
16. Which database do you prefer to ensure scalability – relational or non-relational?
Answer:
 Non-relational databases like MongoDB for dynamic and scalable use cases especially with large or unstructured data.
17. What is gRPC? How does it work and how is it better than REST (HTTP)?
Answer: 
gRPC is a high performance RPC framework using HTTP/2 and Protocol Buffers it's faster and supports bi-directional streaming compared to REST. 
18. Two DSA questions on linked lists 
1. 
Reverse a linked list
2. 
Clone linked list with random pointer
And a few more technical questions related to my projects and course.
Round 3:
 Behavioral + HR Interview Round 
1. Introduce Yourself
I provided a brief overview of my academic background, technical skills, project experiences and areas of interest  mainly backend development and microservices architecture. I also highlighted my enthusiasm for solving real world problems using scalable solutions.
2. Why Choose Maersk?
I expressed my interest in Maersk due to its global impact in logistics and supply chain innovation strong focus on digital transformation and sustainability leadership. The company’s commitment to employee growth and inclusivity also resonated with me.
3. What Are Your Views on Global Sustainability?
I talked about how sustainability in technology and business is essential for the future. I mentioned Maersk’s efforts in achieving net zero emissions and how I’d love to be part of a company that values environmental responsibility.
4. Are You Inspired by Any Project Done by Maersk?
I referred to Maersk's TradeLens blockchain project which aims to bring transparency and efficiency to global trade.
5. Do You Like Reading Books? What Have You Read Recently?
I shared that I enjoy reading non-fiction and recently read "Rich Dad and Poor Dad" and "The Talkative Man by R.K.Narayan" which emphasizes the importance of focused productivity  something I try to practice during development and learning.
6. Was There a Situation of Conflict in Any Project with Your Teammate? How Did You Resolve It?
Yes. I mentioned a minor disagreement over the choice of tech stack in a team project. We resolved it by discussing pros and cons calmly and agreeing on a balanced solution that suited our timeline and learning goals.
7. Where Do You See Yourself in the Next 5 Years?
I said I see myself growing as a strong backend engineer gaining exposure to scalable distributed systems and ideally leading a team or contributing to key projects at Maersk that drive global impact.
8. How Do You Handle Pressure?
I shared that I break down problems into smaller tasks prioritize them and stay calm under deadlines. I also mentioned how proper planning and communication help reduce stress and ensure clarity.
9. What Keeps You Motivated?
Continuous learning, building meaningful software and solving problems that make a real world impact keep me motivated. I enjoy the sense of achievement when a solution works and adds value.
Additional Information
Practice for DSA fundamentals.
Study core CS subjects like Operating Systems, Computer Networks and DBMS.
Practice SQL queries regularly.
Understand your projects deeply you should be able to justify your choices clearly.
Most importantly build strong fundamentals in both programming and systems design.
Closing Note
The overall interview experience with A.P. Moller Maersk was extremely positive. The process was structured  and the questions were aligned with my skill set. I was able to answer almost all the questions effortlessly thanks to my preparation and project experience. I also secured an offer from A.P. Moller - Maersk and I look forward to the exciting journey ahead with a company that values both technical depth and cultural fit.

title: Cognizant Interview Experience for GenC Pro Cybersecurity
content:
Hello Everyone!  Cognizant is a global IT services and consulting company that provides digital, technology, consulting, and operations services. With a strong presence in over 40 countries, Cognizant is known for hiring engineering graduates through its GenC, GenC Pro, and GenC Next programs, catering to both freshers and domain-specialised roles such as Cybersecurity, Full Stack, and Digital Engineering.
How I Got the Interview Call?
I applied for Cognizant through the on-campus placement process. We didn’t register separately for GenC, GenC Pro, or GenC Next. Instead, based on the certificates we uploaded during registration and our performance in the assessments, candidates were shortlisted for specific roles.
After completing the Communication, Aptitude and Gamified, and Technical Assessment rounds, some students were selected for the GenC Pro role, and I was one among them. The entire application and selection process was conducted through Superset.
Recruitment Process Overview
Initial Screening:
Communication Assessment
Aptitude and Gamified Assessment
Technical Assessmen
t
Technical + HR Interview
Round 1: Initial Screening
Once the application was submitted, eligible candidates were automatically shortlisted and received invites for the assessments.
Round 2: Communication Assessment
Date:
 March 13, 2025  
Duration
: 30 minutes  
Mode:
 Online (via Superset)  
Focus Areas:
Communication and listening skills  
Grammar correction  
Sentence formation  
Fluency and pronunciation  
Obstacles
: The audio was fast-paced and required full concentration to answer the comprehension tasks correctly.
Round 3. Aptitude and Gamified Assessment
Date
: March 19, 2025  
Duration
: 90 minutes  
Mode
: Online  
Focus Areas
:
 Quantitative aptitude  
 Logical reasoning  
 Puzzle-solving through gamified scenarios  
Key Tasks
: Pattern recognition, mathematical reasoning, and decision-making in real-time game environments.  
Obstacles
: Adaptive difficulty and tight timing made the puzzles tricky to solve under pressure.
Round 4: Technical Assessment
Date
: March 27, 2025  
Duration
: 60 minutes  
Mode
: Online  
Focus Areas:
 Programming logic  
 Code debugging  
 Output prediction  
Note
: Question difficulty varied based on the student’s assigned technology cluster (mine was Java + SQL).
Round 5:  Technical + HR Interview
Date:
 May 16, 2025  
Duration
: 40–45 minutes  
Mode
: Online Video Interview
Once shortlisted, I received an email from Cognizant/Superset with the interview schedule. The interview platform was a customized virtual meeting room that included integrated code editors and an interview panel. I was notified via both email and SMS when it was my turn to join.
Interview Questions: 
Technical (Cybersecurity, Web, Programming):
Introduce yourself  
What is cryptography and why is it used?  
What are the different types of cryptographic algorithms?  
What is phishing? Types of phishing?  
How do you identify a phishing email?  
Explain penetration testing  
Write a program to print duplicate characters in a string  
How would you improve this program further?  
Difference between Java and JavaScript  
 How to link a CSS file to HTML?  
How to navigate between tabs using HTML?  
Purpose of <canvas> tag  
What validation methods did you use in your projects?  
Use of SQL for data storage and insertion  
SQL query to add a new column  
Explain Joins and Union in SQL  
Difference between DELETE and TRUNCATE  
Using dates/calendars in HTML  
Difference between ordered and unordered lists
HR Questions:
Why are you interested in cybersecurity?  
Rate yourself in Cybersecurity, Java, and SQL  
Willingness to relocate?  
Open to working in shifts?  
Can you join from May 25?  
 Are you comfortable taking up different roles if required?  
 Do you have any questions for us?
Challenges Faced:
Mixture of technical depth and HR questions  
HTML-related syntax of HTML 5 questions were a bit tricky  
Coding questions tested implementation clarity and alternative logic
Post-Interview Refelection
Superset status changed to: “Interim Offer” on May 28, 2025  
Got Letter of Intent (LOI) on “JUNE 19 “ and waiting for further onboarding instructions.
Final Thoughts:
If you're preparing for Cognizant GenC Pro Cybersecurity, make sure your basics in Java, SQL, Cybersecurity, and HTML/CSS are strong. Be confident, speak clearly, and practice mock interviews with behavioral questions. Also, keep an eye on your Superset dashboard and emails for updates!

title: Infosys -DSE| Interview Experience|hackwithinfy
content:
Hello everyone! I am a 2025 graduate, and I applied for Hackwithinfy 2024. The interview process, which eventually led to my selection for the DSE role at Infosys, was an experience filled with anticipation, technical challenges, and learning opportunities.
Recruitment Process Overview
Online Test
Shortlisting for DSE Round
Technical Interview 
Round 1: Online Test
I applied for Hackwithinfy in August 2024. The online assessment consisted of three questions with a time duration of 3 hours. Out of the three, I managed to solve one difficult-level problem, which gave me the confidence to move forward. It was a challenging round, but I was glad to have completed it to the best of my ability.
Obstacles:
Only a select few candidates were able to make it through this round and move on to the next phase. It was a tough start, but I was fortunate enough to be one of them.
Round 2: Shortlisting for DSE Role
After a few months of waiting, I received an email in January 2025 informing me that I had been shortlisted for the DSE role. The email also asked me to select a location for my interview. I chose Bangalore, as it was the most convenient location for me.
Waiting Period:
After selecting the location, there was no communication from Infosys for a few months. This waiting period was long, but I stayed patient and prepared for the interview.
Round 3: Technical Interview
The interviewer started by asking me for a self-introduction. Then, he asked for my opinion on Artificial Intelligence (AI), including its advantages and disadvantages. This was an interesting start, as it gave me a chance to express my thoughts on a current technological topic.
Technical Questions:
After the initial discussion, the interviewer moved on to the technical section. The questions covered various topics, testing my knowledge and problem-solving abilities in different areas:
Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)
 – I was asked questions to demonstrate my understanding of OOP principles.
SQL and ER Diagrams
 – A few questions on SQL queries and Entity-Relationship diagrams were posed.
Coding Challenges
 – I was given three coding problems to solve:
Fibonacci Series without Using a Temporary Variable
ArrayList-related Problem
Exception Handling Problem
The interviewer also asked me to run the code and check its correctness.
Additional Questions:
I was given some code snippets in C language and asked to determine the output.
Questions on HTML and CSS were also asked, focusing on basic concepts and their applications.
The interview was entirely technical, and there were no HR questions. The interviewer did not ask me to explain my projects, which was a bit unusual but didn’t make a significant impact on my performance. The interview lasted for about 45 minutes.
Final Outcome
After the interview, I didn’t hear anything for about 10 days, which felt like an eternity. But then, on April 18th, 2025, I received an email from my TPO (Training and Placement Officer) that I had been selected for the DSE role at Infosys with a package of 6.25 LPA. I was overjoyed and relieved to know that my efforts had paid off.

title: ZOHO Interview Experience for Fresher 2025 {Offcampus}
content:
Hey everyone! I recently appeared for the
 Zoho off-campus drive
 held on 
April 4th,
 and I wanted to share my experience here. The drive saw a huge turnout of around 1500+ candidates, and by the end, only about
 10–12 students
 were shortlisted. Though I couldn’t make it past the third round, I learned a lot and hope this post helps someone preparing for it in the future.
Recruitment Process Overview:
Aptitude + Java Snippets
Coding Round
Low-Level Design (LLD)
Round 1:  Aptitude + Java Snippets
This was the first and major filtration round.
1. Total Questions: 20
10 Aptitude Questions: 
Medium level (time, speed, probability, logical reasoning)
10 Java Code Snippet Questions: 
Tough and conceptually heavy
2. Duration:
 75 minutes
3. Level: 
Tough
4. Shortlisted Candidates: 
Only 90–100 from 1500+
Tip:
 Make sure you’re strong in both 
logic-building and Java fundamentals. 
And yes, practice aptitude thoroughly — it was definitely the toughest round.
Round 2: Coding Round
This was a
 coding round
 with 7 questions of medium level.
Topics Included:
Trees (e.g., Validate BST)
HashMaps
Arrays & Strings
Sliding Window problems (both fixed and variable size)
Questions Asks:
Validate BST
length of longest substring having distinct characters
Check palindrome
FInd first missing Positive
Number of substring having exactly k characters
Find the first non repeating character in a string in 1 pass
Obstacles:
  Around 40–50 candidates cleared this round.
Tip:
 Focus on conceptual clarity and edge case handling. Practicing on platforms like GeeksForGeeks really helps here.
Round 3: Low-Level Design (LLD)
This round was unexpectedly challenging.
Design a
 Task Manager application,
 and the interview was structured in  progressive steps:
Starting from basic design
Adding persistence using local file storage
Handling multiple edge cases and improving functionality step by step
Obstacles
: Only 10–15 students made it to the next technical face-to-face round mostly all of them got selected ig.
Additional Tips
Prepare well for Aptitude: 
This is the most difficult and most important round.
LLD Practice is essential
: Go beyond just DSA.
Get Comfortable with
 
online IDEs: 
You'll be expected to code in them during interviews.
Stay Consistent and Positive
: Even if it doesn't work out, every experience counts.
Final Outcome
Unfortunately, this is where my journey ended. Despite performing decently, I wasn’t shortlisted after LLD. I noticed that most of the candidates selected for the next round were from 
Tamil Nadu
, and while it may have been coincidence, I felt there may have been
 some bias 
— especially considering that a few others and I implemented almost the same solutions as some of the selected candidates.
But that’s life — sometimes it's about more than just the code.

title: Capgemini interview experience (2025 - On Campus)
content:
Recently, I had the opportunity to attempt the Capgemini's Exceller on-campus diversity hiring-female only, grabbed the chance, and boom, the interview went something like: (describing every round in detail as below). The interview was well structured.  
Recruitment Overview Process
Online Assessment
Coding Assessment
Communication Assessment
Round 1: Assessments
Technical assessment
: Had 25 questions; 15 pseudocodes based heavily on finding the output for array, stack, and queue; operations on bitwise and arithmetic operators, post and pre-increment operators (Medium-Hard level). 10 MCQs; all basic questions regarding programming languages and individual DSA theory (Easy peasy).
English Proficiency Assessment:
 MCQs based on grammar, antonyms and synonyms, and fill in the blank with the correct word tense (Smooth & Easy level).
Cognitive test:
 Including games to play, i.e, puzzles to solve within a time limit (Focus and practice helps!) and 75 curated psychometric questions (Individual responses).
Round 2: Coding Assessment
Well, only the top-performing students were able to attempt this round; the rest were moved to the Communication round. Unfortunately, I wasn't one of them. But hey, I qualified for the Spoken English (Communication) round, so yaayy.
Round 3: Communication Assessment
Consisted of four sections: read and repeat, hear and repeat, listen to a conversation and answer the questions, and lastly, a topic was given; 30 seconds to think about it and 45 seconds to speak about it, sounds tough right? but actually pretty do-able if you are NOT distracted. Tip is to focus and try remembering because ticking time waited for none and no repetition was allowed. :-(
Round 4: Technical Interview 
The interview lasted around 25-30 minutes and the few of the questions were asked as below : 
Self-Introduction, what is your final year project, projects made over the years, programming languages I feel comfortable with, basics of SQL, difference between primary and foreign key, what is union and union all and their difference, oops concept with example; what are break, continue and pass, concepts of cpp like pointers, friend function and a program to print palindrome numbers in Python. Agile methodologies and describing the models like waterfall, spiral, SDLC and its stages, and a brief questioning for Analytics tools in Google Analytics (I had mentioned Google Analytics in my resume hence the specific question).
Final Outcome
Heads-up, every round was an elimination round. The interview round was focused mostly on resume, make sure you thoroughly go through the resume, every detail mentioned and certifications done should be revised before the interview. Result? I'm waiting, regardless of the outcome whatever it may be; I hope this experience helps! Toodles .

title: TIAA Interview Experience for Trainee  (On-Campus) 2025
content:
I recently participated in the recruitment process at TIAA for the Software Developer Trainee role. This process included three rounds: an aptitude test, a technical interview, and a managerial round. The experience was insightful, and I’m sharing it here to help others prepare for similar opportunities.
Recruitment Process Overview:
Aptitude Test
Technical Interview
Managerial Round
Round 1
: Aptitude Test
First Round was an Aptitude Test with 2 Coding questions on the CoCubes platform.
Aptitude Section:
 60 questions (20 each from Logical, Verbal, and Quantitative ability) to be completed in 60 minutes.
Coding Section:
 Two coding questions of easy to moderate difficulty with a 30-minute time limit. The coding questions were meant to test problem-solving skills in languages like C/C++ and Java.
I managed to complete the aptitude section with time to spare, and the coding problems were fairly straightforward, allowing me to submit quickly. The faster you submit, the better your chances, so I focused on time management. After completing Part 1 (aptitude), I proceeded to Part 2 (coding) and solved both coding problems. 42 students, including me, were selected from this round.
These are easy-level questions. The sooner you submit, the better your chances — time is key.
Round 2: Technical Interview 
 
The second round was a Technical Interview that was conducted online on Zoom. This round was purely technical. First, I was asked about my Introduction.
I was asked to share my screen and write code to explain the core OOP concepts. They also asked me to provide real-life examples demonstrating how these concepts can be related to practical scenarios.
They also asked me the differences between Java and C++, why I chose C++ for competitive programming, and the difference between a compiler and an interpreter.
What is Big Data? What is the difference between structured and semi-structured data?
What are microservices? Can you give a real-time example?
They gave me some table data and asked me to write SQL queries to retrieve specific information.
They also asked me some questions related to DBMS concepts(Joins, Normalization, DDL, DML). and Operating Systems.
Also asked about the project I mentioned in my resume. We discussed the technologies used, and the interviewer assessed my depth of understanding of those technologies.
They also asked me some questions related to DSA, specifically which data structure is suitable for storing certain types of data.
The second round lasted for 
1 hour
.
Round 3
: 
Managerial Round

title: PayPal Interview Experience For SDE Summer Internshipz
content:
Hello everyone! I am an undergraduate student from Rajasthan, India, and I recently had the opportunity to interview with PayPal. The process consisted of multiple rounds that tested my technical skills, problem-solving ability, and behavioural traits. Here’s a brief overview of my experience:
How do I receive the Interview Call?
The interview opportunity came through an online application, and I was shortlisted after submitting my resume.
Recruitment Process Overview
Online Assessment Round
Technical Round
Managerial Round
Round 1: Online Assessment Round
Difficulty:
 Moderate - Hard
The OA included 6 MCQs and 1 coding problem. The MCQs were of easy difficulty, covering various topics like OOPS, DBS, and Computer Networks (very basic). The coding problem was a challenging string manipulation problem that required using a priority queue with various constraints. I managed to clear 12 out of 15 test cases. I was the only one shortlisted for the upcoming rounds.
Round 2: Technical Round
Difficulty:
 Moderate
The technical interview took place about a month after the OA and consisted of 3 coding problems. The first was an easy DP grid problem, which I solved within 10 minutes. The second was another standard DP question (LIS), which I also solved. The third was a hard string manipulation problem that had a unique solution using stacks. I wasn’t required to code the solution. The interview then focused on discussing my projects, followed by related questions. It concluded with an HR question.
Round 3: Managerial Round
Difficulty:
 Moderate
The managerial interview also took place about a month after the technical interview. It kicked off with a couple of brain-teasers, I was asked 2-3 real-life scenario problems and how I would use unique methods to solve them. These solutions ranged from using DBMS concepts to system interrupts(a debugging feature used in production code). Then, we had an in-depth discussion about React and JavaScript (since I had a project related to it on my resume). The interview ended with a light-hearted discussion about the work location, as I had also lived there.
Final Outcome
Having a strong resume and solid coding skills is only half of the equation. The other factors include your soft skills, ability to communicate effectively, and sometimes, just a bit of luck. Keep working on these aspects, and success will follow!
Good luck to all the future candidates!

title: Cognizant Interview Experience for Genc /Genc Pro/Genc Next 2025 - Off-Campus
content:
This is about my recent interview experience with Cognizant, which was conducted off-campus through the Superset platform in May 2025. The recruitment process was well-structured and consisted of four rounds: a Communication round, an Aptitude + Reasoning (Game-Based) Round, a Technical Assessment, and finally a combined Technical + HR Interview.
Recruitment Process Overview
The Cognizant recruitment process had 4 rounds:
Communication Test
Aptitude + Reasoning (Game-Based Assessment)
Technical Assessment
Technical + HR Interview
After applying via the Superset platform, nearly 1 month later, I got the communication round test link.
Round 1: Communication Round 
Duration:
 60 minutes
Method:
 Virtual
Focus:
 English , Fluency, Grammar.
Obstacles:
 In this round , one section consists of an audio which will be played only once and you have to repeat after it. So please be careful.
After 3-4 days , I got test link for aptitude round.
Round 2: Aptitude Round
Duration
: 80 mins
Method
: Virtual
Focus
: 30 aptitude questions followed by 4 sections of gamified assessments.
Obstacles
: In Gamified you should reach maximum level as you can to increase you chances of selection.
After 1 day , I got test link for technical assessment prior to 3 days.
Round 3:
 Technical Assessment:
It consisted of 2 coding(java) , 2 sql , 1 web development (html , css , js ) questions .
I am very much familiar with c++. But it has only options for Java , python , c#. So I have opted Java.
I have selected the default cluster which is Java , so I have to do the coding in Java only. 
I solved both coding questions and both sql questions and I solved the html , css part and didn't solve the js part of last question.
After 3 days , I got mail that I was shortlisted for virtual interview.
Round 4:
 Technical Interview:
I have been alloted a slot of 4-6 pm . After waiting for long time my interview started  at 5:30pm .
The Interviewer asked me to introduce myself. 
I am not much familiar with java coding ( I know only the basics and not much with development, in technical assessment I have solved the questions since they were easy and didn't need any collections to solve).
So I introduce myself with my background and mentioned that I am interested towards AI/ML so that I can get questions based on that and also told , I use c++ for problem solving and only java basics.
He gave 2 questions to solve : given two arrays, you need to find the common elements . and given a strong which contains a letter twice and you need to find it.
These were the easy questions that , I've got since I'm already familiar with easy-medium level questions on GFG with cpp.
But , I couldn't even write error free code in java and the same for the second question as well . But I have explained him the logic but he asked me to write the code .
Then , I asked if I could write in c++ . But he said I want in java only.
At that Moment, i knew that it was all over. Then he asked me some OOPS questions and winded it up.
He also asked about the Relocation and flexibilty to work in night shifts.
Final Outcome
So , the technical interview will be purely based on the cluster and the resume. 
I have felt like targeting FAANG to being 
rejected by Cognizant
, i have came a long way.
Btw , I am currently working as an intern (6 months) , not a reputed one but.

title: My Kota Coaching Experience as a 2022 12th Passout (Covid Batch)
content:
Hey Everyone!
I just wanted to share my journey preparing for JEE after passing 12th in 2022. My experience was shaped by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, which disrupted my learning and preparation.
The Impact of the Pandemic
I was part of the most affected Covid batch — both 11th and 12th were mostly online. Because of this, I didn’t get to meet friends, had no proper guidance from teachers, and honestly, I had no idea what JEE or engineering preparation really meant. Coming from a small town where there's no proper coaching for the JEE. Very few students even attempt the exam here. So by the end of the 12th, I was still clueless about how to start. I had taken PCM, so engineering was the obvious choice — but I didn’t know where or how to prepare.
Discovering JEE and Motion Coaching 
One day, I watched the Kota Factory series, and that’s when I first heard of IIT-JEE. Jeetu Bhaiya’s and NV Sir’s dialogues really hit me. That’s how I found out about NV Sir and 
Motion Coaching Institute.
Joining Motion Coaching Institute
My 12th board exams ended on 13 June 2022. I called Motion for details, and they told me NV Sir would teach 1/3rd of Physics. I was excited and decided to take a drop year. I joined Motion on 22 June.
The Initial Phase: Excitement and Enthusiasm
Initially, it felt good — same subjects (PCM), same enthusiasm. For the first 2 to 2.5 months, the pace was slow, and I was understanding everything. I genuinely felt that I could crack IIT.
The Struggles: Fast-Paced Dropper Batch
However, things soon changed. Since it was a dropper batch, the pace picked up significantly. By September, we were studying three chapters simultaneously in each subject — a total of 9 chapters at once. These chapters were taught by different teachers, and the pace felt overwhelming.
My batch had around 400 students, which made it difficult to get doubts cleared. Although there were separate doubt-solving faculties, they often used different methods from the class teachers, which only added to the confusion.
Disappointment with NV Sir’s Limited Involvement
Another major disappointment was that NV Sir, who was supposed to teach 1/3rd of Physics, only taught a small part of optics — just the mirror portion. This was quite disappointing, as I had expected more from his classes.
Coaching Setbacks: Delayed Start and Quality Issues
The batch started late (end of June), and proper teaching began only around September. To make matters worse, NTA announced JEE Mains in January instead of April, which meant that by that point, only around 45-50% of the syllabus had been completed.
Additionally, Motion shifted all the best teachers to the top "Star Batch." Our batch (a lower one) had mostly less experienced teachers, which significantly affected the quality of preparation. Overall, I would rate my experience at Motion a 3/5. The coaching had potential, but poor planning and miscommunication really let it down.
Taking Charge: Self-Preparation and Smart Planning
Realizing that my coaching wasn’t enough, I decided to take control of my preparation. In December, I started studying from PW’s free YouTube batch and created a strict timetable for myself. I listed chapters with deadlines and stuck this plan on my wall. With consistent effort and discipline, I managed to cover almost 70% of the syllabus on my own within a month.
I focused on solving Previous Year Questions (PYQs), understanding key concepts, and revising regularly. This self-discipline and smart planning helped me immensely.
The Outcome: Success at JEE Mains
Thanks to my focused approach, I was able to clear JEE Mains. Today, I’m proud to say that I’m studying at 
IIIT Nagpur
. This journey taught me the real value of consistency, discipline, and taking control of your own preparation.
Final Thoughts
I hope my journey helps someone make an informed decision about their JEE preparation. While coaching institutes can provide guidance, personal dedication and consistency are what truly matter.

content:
Recently, I appeared for an interview targeting the role of Application Developer. The recruitment process was accurate, well-structured, and included multiple rounds assessing various technical skills and behavioural traits.

Technical Interview 3

: Online Assessment

 1 hard-level coding question + 20 MCQs (DBMS, OS, aptitude, verbal reasoning)

 Managing time between coding and multiple-choice sections

 1 hour

Bottom view of a binary tree

Tree vs Graph logic (Cycle detection)

OOP and JavaScript fundamentals (from resume)

 1 hour

 In-person

 Advanced DSA + problem-solving approach

 Demonstrating adaptability and structured problem-solving under pressure

Prepare well for HR, ask thoughtful questions at the end, and be confident about what’s listed on your resume.
