title: Infosys Interview Experience for System engineer
content:
I recently participated in the Infosys recruitment process for the role of System Engineer and am happy to share that I was selected. The recruitment was held through a pool-campus, with the results being declared in January 2025. I'm excited about this opportunity and look forward to joining Infosys as a System Engineer.
Recruitment Process Overview
The recruitment process has only two rounds
Written Test
HR/Technical Round
Round 1: Online Test (Written Assessment)
The first round was an online written test comprising 7 sections, including:
Duration
: 2 hours
Mode
: Online
The first round was an online written test comprising 7 sections, including:
Aptitude
Logical Reasoning 
Verbal Ability
Mental Ability
Basic Programming (5 code snippets)
Pseudocode-based Questions
Essay Writing
There was no negative marking, no sectional timing, and the flow was not unidirectional, which was a great relief. We were informed in the pre-talk that scoring above 75% in each section was crucial to move forward, along with an overall cutoff.
The difficulty level was easy to moderate, and overall, I found the test to be manageable without much preparation.
Round 2: Technical + HR Interview
Duration
: 20 minutes
Mode
: Offline
Difficulty
: Easy
I received the interview call a day after the test, and the interview was scheduled for the next morning at 9 AM. I wasn’t expecting such a quick turnaround, so I had to rush to make it to the venue on time.
The interviewer was calm and made me feel comfortable throughout. The interaction covered both technical and HR questions.
Technical Questions:
Explained my Capstone Project in detail
Asked to write a Palindrome program
Asked which language I preferred: Java or Python, and why
HR Questions:
Have you done any activities other than academics?
You've studied in your hometown throughout; will you be able to relocate?
Why do you prefer taking up a job instead of going for higher studies?
Describe a stressful situation and how you managed it
What’s your opinion on Generative AI?
How do you use AI in your daily life?
Since my resume mentioned
 AI & ML specialization
, the interviewer asked me about a recent AI trend released the previous day. Unfortunately, I wasn’t aware of it as I hadn’t checked the news. He even tried to give hints, but I couldn’t answer it correctly.
Despite that, the interview ended on a positive note with a "Good luck and all the best!" from the interviewer.
Tips for Future Aspirants
Be prepared to talk about your projects and resume points in detail
Brush up on basic coding questions (like palindrome, prime number, etc.)
Stay updated with the latest technology trends, especially if your resume highlights related skills
Be confident and honest if you don’t know something
You don’t need to prepare heavily for the written test – the questions are basic and very doable.
Final Verdict
A few days later, the results were announced, and 
I was selected
 for the 
System Engineer
 role at Infosys.
Note: 
After one month, Infosys conducted upgradation interviews for selected candidates. Based on performance and merit, some candidates were offered roles in Digital Specialist Engineer (DSE) and Specialist Programmer (SP) with higher packages. This was a great opportunity for those who performed well to move into more challenging and rewarding roles — 
definitely a huge bonus in the overall process!
Wishing everyone the best of luck!

title: Interview Experience at IIT Kanpur for MS in Signal Processing
content:
Hello GATE aspirants!
 If you’re aiming for an MS at IIT Kanpur, especially in the Electrical Engineering department with a focus on Signal Processing, here’s a detailed look at the interview process from my experience. I appeared for GATE 2025 in Electronics and Communication, scoring 542 with an All India Rank (AIR) of 2006 in the General category, and was shortlisted among 35 candidates nationwide for this opportunity.
Shortlisting & Interview Call
Based on my GATE score and rank, I was shortlisted for the MS program in Signal Processing at IIT Kanpur. For context, only 35 candidates were shortlisted from all across India, making the competition very tight. The interview call came via email. The interview was conducted offline with an option for online mode, but I chose to appear physically on campus. This program is well-regarded for its rigorous academic and research standards, making the interview stage a crucial step.
Preparation for the Interview
I focused heavily on core signal processing topics, including fundamentals of signals and systems, Fourier and Laplace transforms, and digital signal processing techniques. Additionally, I revised mathematical concepts such as linear algebra, calculus, probability, and statistics, which are important for signal processing theory. I practiced explaining concepts clearly and solving numerical problems. Although I did not have formal mock interviews, rehearsing answers aloud helped me prepare.
Interview Day Experience
The interview lasted about 20 minutes and was conducted by a panel of 2 professors specializing in electrical engineering and signal processing. It started with a brief self-introduction and questions about the subjects I prepared. The questions tested my understanding of linear algebra, probability, and mathematical plotting.
Choosing to attend the interview physically was motivating. Being on campus allowed me to interact informally with professors and students, observe the academic environment, and learn about ongoing research projects. This exposure gave me a better understanding of the institute’s culture and academic expectations, which helped me mentally prepare for the interview.
Interview Questions Asked
Here’s a detailed rundown of the questions I faced:
Briefly describe yourself.
Which subjects did you prepare? (I mentioned Linear Algebra and Probability.)
Explain linear independence of vectors and orthogonality. They asked how to plot these concepts in vector space and presented various cases on the same plot.
On probability, they asked about sigma algebra (which I was not familiar with).
Explain mutually exclusive and independent events using Venn diagrams. I could explain mutually exclusive well but struggled with independence. They gave an example of dice throw — odd numbers set and divisible by 3 set — and asked me to explain how these are mutually exclusive and independent using Venn diagrams. I explained mutually exclusive properly but got stuck on independent events.
Then they asked about plotting functions:
Plot log(1/x) — I took some time but answered.
Plot 1/(x log(1/x)) and overlap it on log(1/x) — I struggled a bit but managed after repeated attempts.
Plot sin(x) and sin²(x) in the range 0 to π — I initially drew it correctly it after being asked to take time.
The interview lasted around 20 minutes. At the end, I asked for feedback and was told I needed to work more on basics rather than just examples.
Tips for Future Aspirants
Strengthen your fundamentals in linear algebra, probability, and mathematical concepts rather than relying on examples alone.
Practice plotting common functions and interpreting their graphs.
Be prepared to explain concepts like vector spaces, event independence, and sigma algebra clearly.
Rehearse your self-introduction and be ready to discuss your preparation strategy.
If possible, attend the interview physically to get a feel for the campus environment and interact with faculty and students.
Stay calm, think aloud during problem-solving, and listen carefully to hints from the interviewers.
Conclusion
The IIT Kanpur MS interview in Signal Processing was concise but probing, focusing on core mathematics and conceptual clarity. For those preparing, focus on basics, practice graphical questions, and communicate your thought process clearly. Visiting the campus physically gave me motivation and valuable insight into the institute’s research culture. Feel free to reach out if you want to discuss the interview or preparation strategies in more detail!

title: Unlock Strategies To Memorize Vast GATE Syllabus
content:
Are you struggling to cover your entire GATE syllabus like other aspirants? No need to stress out! We've got a secret strategy that every GATE aspirant should incorporate into their preparation journey. By following our mentioned approach, even the vast and challenging syllabus will become interesting and manageable to all aspiring candidates.
We often hear that many GATE aspirants fail to clear the examination. Have you ever wondered what the reason is behind it? It is not because of their lack of knowledge regarding the subjects but because they are unable to cover the entire GATE syllabus on time.  The GATE CSE paper consists of 12 subjects, right from General Aptitude to Data Structures and Algorithms. Each subject comprises 10-12 subtopics, and covering all 12 subjects, along with managing revision and test series, seems nearly impossible for many aspirants.
If you are among those candidates who are going to appear for the upcoming GATE examination, then you have landed at the right place. In today's article, let us explore strategies that may aid aspirants in memorizing the vast syllabus.
Focus on Fundamentals
A strong foundation is crucial in your GATE preparation. Starting with a structured approach is essential. Begin by mastering the fundamentals of each subject. Here’s how you can do that:
Start with One Topic at a Time:
 Focus on individual subjects and complete one topic before moving on to the next. This ensures that you don’t feel overwhelmed.
Prepare Notes:
 While studying a topic, take notes and immerse yourself in its theory and concepts. Once you are confident with a topic, move on to solving previous year’s questions (PYQs) to solidify your understanding.
Repeat the Process:
 Once you complete one topic, move on to the next, solve its PYQs, and repeat the cycle until you cover all topics.
The key is to 
master one topic before moving to the next
, which will help you stay organized and ensure a strong grasp of concepts.
Complete the Syllabus 4 Months Before the Exam
Once you are done with covering the entire syllabus beforehand, dedicate the remaining 4-5 months to revising all your concepts. Adopt the revision cycle formula to ensure that you have sufficient time in hand for in-depth understanding and revising your weak points. Make a target to complete your first revision cycle within a week by creating the subnotes (ensure to limit them to 3-4 pages only), which serve as a quick reference for revisiting the concepts a day before the exam and then solving the previously solved PYQs again. When done, go for the unsolved PYQs.
Implement the Revision Cycle Formula
Once you’ve completed the entire syllabus, use the remaining 4-5 months for 
dedicated revision
. Adopting the 
Revision Cycle Formula
 will help you revise efficiently and ensure you’re well-prepared for the exam.
First Revision:
 Target to complete your first revision cycle within a week. Create 
concise sub-notes
 (limit them to 3-4 pages per topic), which serve as quick reference material for last-minute revision.
PYQs:
 After completing the first revision, solve the previously solved PYQs again. Once done, move on to the unsolved PYQs to test your retention.
Repeat the Cycle:
 Repeat this process for 3 months. By the end of this cycle, you will have covered around 90% of the PYQs across all topics.
This continuous revision approach will help you internalize the concepts and increase your chances of success in the GATE exam.
The Importance of Test Series
The last two months before the GATE exam are important for refining your strategy. Dedicate these two months completely to 
taking test series
. Here’s why:
Familiarity with Question Pattern:
 Regularly taking test series helps you become familiar with the GATE exam format, time limits, and the types of questions asked.
Time Management:
 It sharpens your time management skills, ensuring you can solve questions within the given time.
Understanding the Question:
 Many aspirants stress over scoring high marks without properly understanding the questions. It’s important to read each question 2-3 times before attempting to solve it. Quality over quantity is key.
Identify Weak Areas:
 Test series help identify your strengths and weaknesses, allowing you to focus on areas that need improvement.
The more tests you take, the better prepared you’ll be. This strategy ensures that you’re not just memorizing answers but truly understanding the material.
What to do now? - Let’s Conclude
Now, there is no need to panic on seeing the vast GATE syllabus. Include the above hacks and re-revise your preparation strategy accordingly to ensure the entire syllabus coverage and revision on time before appearing for the examination. Get one step closer to excelling in the upcoming GATE examination. 
Good luck with your preparation!

title: TCS Interview Experience for Ninja Role (Verdict : Selected)
content:
I applied for a position in November 2024, and the process turned out to be an interesting and enriching experience. Here's a breakdown of the journey:
Eligibility Criteria:
Final-year student seeking thesis/internship opportunities.
Academic background with strong foundational knowledge (0–1 years relevant academic experience).
Recruitment Process Overview:
Initial Screening
Technical Round
HR Round
Round 1: Initial Screening
Duration:
 Around 2–3 hours (online/offline exam center)
Method:
 In-person (exam center)
Focus:
 Aptitude and Data Structures & Algorithms test (TCS format)
Key Questions:
Quantitative aptitude (math problems, logical reasoning)
DSA coding and logic problems
Obstacles:
 Time pressure during the exam, balancing aptitude and coding questions
Round 2: Technical Round
Duration:
 Approximately 40–45 minutes
Method
: In-person (on-campus)
Focus:
 Data Structures and Algorithms, CS fundamentals (OOPs, DBMS), logic puzzles
Key Questions:
Swap two numbers without using a third variable, STL, or XOR → Required to find alternate method (addition/subtraction approach)
Print numbers in a given range that divide a number a
Puzzle:
 "If 5 machines make 5 pens in 5 minutes, how long will 100 machines take to make 100 pens?"
Puzzle:
 "Bird lands on a 50kg car on a 50kg limit bridge – will it still cross?"
Puzzle:
 "How to divide a cake into 8 pieces using 3 straight cuts?"
OOPs:
 Abstraction, encapsulation, inheritance, constructor overloading, method overloading vs. overriding, static vs. dynamic binding
DBMS:
 3-level view architecture, primary key vs. unique key, SQL JOIN query
Some Java-related OOPs questions (despite C++ background)
Obstacles:
Unexpected twist on the swap question (had to come up with a 4th approach)
Some Java-specific OOPs questions despite primary focus on C++
One puzzle was difficult to recall, but I attempted a logical answer nonetheless
Round 3:
 HR Round
Duration
: 10–15 minutes
Method
: In-person
Focus
: Behavioral and situational judgement
Key Questions:
Have you faced any conflict in a team? How did you handle it?
What if someone in your team refuses to work?
If there’s a bug in the final product, would you inform the client?
Are you willing to relocate?
Obstacles:
 None — The HR round was conversational and relaxed.
Post-Interview Reflections
Company Culture Insights:
 Friendly and problem-solving focused. The interviewers encouraged thinking aloud and appreciated logical problem-solving.
Work Environment
: Conducted on campus, so no direct insight into company environment, but interviewers seemed supportive and professional.
Benefits Highlight:
 Not discussed during this process.
Evaluator Feedback: 
Positive overall. The interviewers seemed to value my honesty and ability to think on the spot, which helped me get selected.
Suggestions for Improvement: 
It would be helpful if candidates were given clearer info about expected languages or topics to better prepare for language-specific questions.
Additional Information
The exam and interview were conducted smoothly and results were shared quickly. I was selected, which was a big confidence booster.
Final Outcome
I was selected.

title: TCS Prime Interview Experience | Off-Campus 2024
content:
Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) is one of the leading global IT services, consulting, and business solutions organisations. TCS offers various hiring roles, such as Ninja, Digital, and Prime, based on the performance in the TCS National Qualifier Test (NQT). The Prime role is offered to candidates with strong technical and problem-solving skills.
How I Got the Opportunity
I applied through the 
TCS NQT 2024 Off-Campus Drive
, which was held in April 2024. This is a yearly drive open to all final-year students across India.
Recruitment Overview Process
TCS NQT Exam
Interview (TR + MR + HR Combined)
Round 1: TCS NQT Exam
The TCS NQT exam had the following structure:
Aptitude Section:
 Verbal Reasoning, Quantitative Aptitude, Logical Reasoning
Coding Section (2 Questions):
Find the sum of cubes from 1 to a given number n.
Given a list of products with price and quantity sold, we had to:
Calculate total sales
Find the average sales
Identify the best-selling product
The logic wasn’t hard, but the input format was a bit tricky, and many faced issues viewing the output. There was a small arrow we had to click to see the printed output, even I discovered it around 15 minutes before time ended, but managed to submit it successfully.
After clearing NQT, I received a mail for the interview (Prime role).
Round 2: Interview (TR + MR + HR Combined)
The panel had three interviewers – technical, managerial, and HR.
Started with a brief introduction and questions about my family background.
Project Discussion:
What is your project about?
Is it live? – Since I had added the project link in my resume, I showed them the hosted application on one of the interviewer's mobile phones.
What was your role in project?
What’s new in your project compared to existing ones?
What is JWT token used in your application?
They seemed quite interested in the live demo and asked follow-up questions based on what they saw.
Technical Questions:
Difference between final and finally
Exception handling
Data types and data structures
What is a binary tree?
4 pillars of OOP
Difference between DML and DDL
Types of locks in DBMS
Coding Question:
Swap two numbers without using a third variable. 
The question was easy, but the panel asked me to explain multiple approaches to solve it.
They were mainly checking problem-solving skills, how I think through multiple solutions, and my understanding of the logic behind it.
Managerial Questions:
What do you know about TCS?
Why do you want to join TCS?
Would you work on old technologies if required?
Would you prefer:
Working alone on a latest tech project, or
Working in a team on a smaller project?
Cloud & Tech Awareness:
What is Cloud Computing? What are its types?
Difference between Public, Private, and Hybrid Cloud
Explain IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS with examples
HR Questions:
Your strengths and weaknesses
Your 10th, 12th, and graduation percentages
Any backlogs or education gaps
Willing to relocate?
Do you have any questions for Dus?
Final Outcome
Selected for Prime Role.
